content:
Conservative prime ministers are the most generous with knighthoods

THE DECISION by Theresa May to reward a fellow Conservative, John Hayes, with a knighthood in November drew criticism, as it was seen as a move to quell his vocal opposition to the government’s Brexit deal. But awarding sitting MPs with knighthoods is not unusual, at least for Tory governments. The prime minister, unaffected by the opprobrium, dished out knighthoods to more of her colleagues in the New Year’s list, including one for a leading Eurosceptic, John Redwood (who says he will still vote down her Brexit deal).

Britain’s system of knighthoods is anachronistic and idiosyncratic. The centuries-old rewards of chivalry started in 1348 with the Order of the Garter . Other eccentric titles followed. The Order of the Thistle relating to Scottish service was introduced in 1687. The Order of the Bath for senior military officers and civil servants came in 1725. There is also a baffling hierarchy to these gongs. The second-lowest honour, and the most recent addition to the system, is the Order of the British Empire , which was created by King George V in 1917 to recognise outstanding efforts by non-combatants during the first world war. The Knight Bachelor, the most common knighthood bestowed upon sitting MPs, is technically the lowest. Although it entitles the holder to be called “Sir”, it does not bring membership of any of the organised orders of chivalry. But this distinction will mean little to most of the population (or MPs).

Worries about the use of undue influence to obtain a coveted title are nothing new. In late 1917 concerns were raised about financial inducements and the newly created honour. A royal commission found improprieties relating to political parties. Abuse of the system would later be made a criminal offence. In 1966 a Labour prime minister, Harold Wilson, put a stop to honours being given purely for political service. But the next Tory prime minister reversed the ruling, and since then some 175 sitting Tory MPs have been rewarded for loyal service. Whether Mrs May’s generosity to fellow Parliamentarians is repaid with loyalty in turn should become apparent later this month when her Brexit deal comes before Parliament.

Title: Gongs galore: how the British honours system rewards politicians

paperStatistics.title: Gongs galore: how the British honours system rewards politicians
paperStatistics.desc: Conservative prime ministers are the most generous with knighthoods
